chapter.title: Scripting with Lua
chapter.para: darktable comes with a versatile scripting interface for functionality enhancement.

In a typical use case you define actions which are performed when certain events are triggered. One example is calling an external application during file export in order to perform additional processing steps.

darktable uses Lua, which is an independent project founded in 1993, providing a powerful, fast, lightweight, embeddable scripting language. Lua is widely used by many open source applications, in commercial programs, and for game programming.

sect1.title: Lua usage
sect1.para: This section documents the principles of Lua developement.

listitem.para: darktable uses Lua version 5.2, see Lua reference manual
for a documentation of darktable's Lua API see
for user provided scripts see

sect2.title: A note about beta
sect2.para: darktable's Lua API is still in a beta phase of development. This has multiple implications you should be aware of when writing Lua code:

listitem.para: The API might change without notice. In particular if we find out that the API is not practical.
The API is incomplete. If you find something missing please report on IRC, in the mailing list, or open a feature request.

darktable's Lua API is generally limited to the lighttable view. In other words we aim at being able to do with Lua everything that can be done in the lighttable, but anything that can only be done in darkroom mode is off-limit.

sect2.title: Basic principles
sect2.para: At startup, darktable will run two Lua scripts:

listitem.para: a script called rc.lua in $DARKTABLE/share/darktable
a script called rc.lua in the user's configuration directory

sect2.para: $DARKTABLE is used here to represent your system's darktable installation directory.
This is the only time darktable will run Lua scripts by itself. Scripts can register callbacks to perform actions. See the corresponding section in .

sect2.title: Handling scripts
sect2.para: darktable will look for Lua modules in the system provided Lua path, but it will also look into the following places:

listitem.para: $(CONFIG_DIR)/lua/?.lua
$(USER_DIR)/lua/?.lua

sect2.para: In other word, if you place a file called c.lua in the directory ~/.config/darktable/lua/a/b/ then @require "a.b.c" will find your script. The normal way to install a script is to copy it in ~/.config/darktable/lua/ then adding a require line to the file ~/.config/darktable/rc.lua.

sect1.title: Lua API
sect1.para: To access the darktable specific functions you must first load the darktable environment:
All functions and data are accessed through this environment.

sect2.title: darktable.print_error
sect2.para: This function will print its parameter if the Lua logdomain is activated.
Syntax: darktable.print_error(<string>)

listitem.para: the string to print

sect2.title: darktable.database
sect2.para: Allows to access the database of images, note that duplicate images (images with the same RAW but different XMP) will appear multiple times with different duplicate indexes
Images are indexed as in a table and can be iterated with ipairs, but not directly added or deleted.
Syntax: darktable.database : table-like of images

sect2.title: database.duplicate
sect2.para: Creates a duplicate of an image and returns it.
Syntax: database.duplicate(image)

listitem.para: the image to duplicate
the new image object

sect2.title: database.import
sect2.para: Imports the corresponding directory or file.
Syntax: database.import(<path or file>)
If it is an image, returns the image object.
If it is a directory, returns the corresponding film object.
NOTE: if the image are set to be imported recursively in preferences, only the toplevel film is returned (the one whose path was given as a parameter).

NOTE2: if the parameter is a directory, the call is non-blocking. The film object will not have the newly imported images yet. Use a post-import-film filtering on that film to react when images are actually imported.

sect2.title: darktable.films
sect2.para: Pseudo table containing objects describing the films.

sect2.title: darktable.preferences
sect2.para: Lua allows you do manipulate preferences. Lua has its own namespace for preferences and you can't access nor write normal darktable preferences.

Preference-handling functions take a script parameter. This is a string used to avoid name collision in preferences (i.e namespace). Set it to something unique, usually the name of the script handling the preference.
Preference-handling functions can't guess the type of a parameter. You must pass the type of the preference you are handling. Allowed values are string, bool, and integer.

sect3.title: darktable.preferences.register
sect3.para: Creates a new preference entry in the Lua tab of the preference screen. If this function is not called the preference can't be set by the user (you can still read and write invisible preferences).
Syntax: darktable.preferences.register(script, name, type, label, tooltip, default, [min, max])

listitem.para: invisible prefix to guarentee unicity of preferences
the name of the preference displayed in the preference screeen
the type of the preference
the tooltip to display
default value
(int only) minimum value
(int only) maximum value

sect3.title: darktable.preferences.read
sect3.para: Reads a value from a Lua preference.
Syntax: darktable.preferences.read(script, name, type) : value

listitem.para: an invisible prefix
name of the preference to read
the type of the preference to read
the value of the preference

sect3.title: darktable.preferences.write
sect3.para: Writes a value to a Lua preference.
Syntax: darktable.preferences.write(script, name, type, value)

listitem.para: an invisible prefix
name of the preference to set
type of the preference to write
value to set

sect2.title: darktable.print
sect2.para: Will print a string to the darktable control log (the long overlayed window that appears over the main panel).
Syntax: darktable.print(string)

listitem.para: the string to display, should be a single line

sect3.title: darktable.gui.selection
sect3.para: Allows to change the set of selected images.
Syntax: darktable.gui.selection(<selection>)

It is recommanded to use this table to implement Lua actions rather than dt.gui.hovered or dt.gui.selected to be consistant with darktable's gui.
Syntax: dt.gui.action_images : table

sect2.title: darktable.register_storage
sect2.para: Allows to implement a new storage that will be entirely implemented in Lua. The user provides a callback that will be called once for each image, and a second callback that will be called when all images are processed.
Syntax: darktable.register_storage(plugin_name, name, [store], [finalize], [supported])

listitem.para: unique name for the plugin
human readable name for the plugin

term.emphasis: store(storage, image, format, filename, num, total, high_quality, extra_data)

listitem.para: this function is called once for each exported image; store can not be called concurrently but the exporting pipe is run in the background for other images while Lua callbacks are called
this function is called once all images are processed and all store calls are finished

this function is called once for each format and must return a boolean; if the function isn't provided, all formats will be accepted; note that the format object has the current gui settings for that format, not the values that will be used at export time

The event is triggered whenever the shortcut is triggered.
This event has one extra parameter at registration time.

sect1.title: Lua scripts
sect1.para: This section presents a list of scripts provided by beta testers of the Lua API. There is no guarentee whatsoever that they will work. The API is still in beta and might have changed since the script was uploaded.

sect2.title: Simple mosaic script

listitem.para: author: boucman
tested with: 1.3+265~gd7f3d1a
download: mosaic.lua

sect2.programlisting:
dt = require "darktable" dt.register_storage("module_stitcher","mosaic generator",nil, function(storage,image_table) dt.print_error("Will try to stitch now") command = "gm convert " for _,v in pairs(image_table) do command = command..v.." " end command = command.."-append -resize 15% " ..dt.configuration.tmp_dir.."/tmp.png" dt.print_error("this is the command: "..command) os.execute(command)
dt.print("Stitching saved to "..dt.configuration.tmp_dir .."/tmp.png") end )
sect2.para: This script is an example of storage implemented in Lua. This is not complete nor polished but it shows how to implement a storage module in Lua.
The script must be saved in ~/.config/darktable/lua/ (the directory might not exist).
Add the following line in the file ~/.config/darktable/rc.lua (again, the file might not exist):
A new entry mosaic generator will be added to the storage list. Using it will create a mosaic of selected images in a temporary directory.
Thanks to hal_from_2001 for the idea an the original implementation.

sect2.title: Selection manipulation shortcuts

listitem.para: author: boucman
tested with: 1.3+265~gd7f3d1a
download: save_selection.lua

sect2.programlisting:
dt = require "darktable" local buffer_count = 5
for i=1,buffer_count do local saved_selection dt.register_event("shortcut",function() saved_selection = dt.gui.selection() end,"save to buffer "..i) dt.register_event("shortcut",function() dt.gui.selection(saved_selection) end,"restor from buffer "..i) end
local bounce_buffer = {} dt.register_event("shortcut",function() bounce_buffer = dt.gui.selection(bounce_buffer) end,"switch selection with temporary buffer")
sect2.para: This script will add a couple of shortcuts to help manipulate selection.
The script must be saved in ~/.config/darktable/lua/ (the directory might not exist).
Add the following line in the file ~/.config/darktable/rc.lua (again, the file might not exist):
New options will appear under global->lua. These shortcuts allow you to save and restore the current selection to/from five different save bufffers.
There is also a shortcut to exchange the current selection with the content of a fast buffer.

sect2.title: Enable error logging
sect2.para: The first step to debugging Lua is to enable Lua logging. this is done by enabling the Lua logdomain with the command line argument -d lua.

listitem.para: Messages printed by a Lua script using darktable.print_error will be visible on the standard out.
In case of Lua error, the whole traceback (and not just the error message) will be printed to the console.

sect2.title: Analyzing data
sect2.para: darktable provides some debugging helpers. Below is an example:
sect2.programlisting:
dt_debug = require "darktable.debug" dt_debug.debug.debug = true
print(dt_debug.dump(_G,"Global environement")
sect2.para: The main function provided is darktable.debug.dump(object,name). This function returns a string that describes an object. The object can be anything and this function will use its knowledge of the darktable API to be smart about the type of objects.

The boolean variable darktable.debug.debug is initialized to false. When this variable is set true, dt_debug.dump will also dump metatables for objects. You usually only want to see those when debugging the internals of darktable's Lua API.

sect2.title: Debugging unprotected calls
sect2.para: When experimenting with Lua, darktable might crash with the following message:
sect2.programlisting: PANIC: unprotected error in call to lua API (some message here)
sect2.para: This is always a bug in darktable's Lua API. Please open a bug report and attach the script that caused the crash.
